item.title: Algorithmic art from classic books, January 2014
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This was my first foray into visual programming using pygame.

I wrote a python script with an algorithm that took letters and converted them into a given height and colour then displayed these letters as lines of different colours in a window with a background colour determined by the length of the string of text. There were a number of issues with my plan as the numbers which the letters were converted to were all fairly similar, there was no great distance between them, meaning that the colours and heights were fairly similar. These issues can be seen above. To overcome the issue of colour I added some equations in to vary the colours depending on its position in the string and the length of the word etc. It proved difficult to get three numbers from the letters of one hex code   . I overcame the issues with height differences by making each of the height values a percentage of the height of the window.

By this time I had something vaguely resembling a program to convert the world of words to our visual world, via the world of computers. I thought this fitted rather neatly with the topic, constructed world.  the results, though interesting and sometimes beautiful with obscure characters were not good enough. I suddenly had the idea to convert not just the world of words but the world of literature into one of these pictures. I searched on Project Gutenberg, a website where out of copyright books are converted to digital and distributed for free, for a text file of a favourite classic of mine, A Picture of Dorian Gray. Having found it, with the knowledge that quotation marks would break my code, I removed unnecessary whitespace and quotation marks from the text until I had just the words. I then inserted these into the message variable of my program.

There are something like 400,000 letters in this book and I had no idea why my program was not putting the lines on the screen, but it turns out that the resolution of the window (how many pixels wide and hight it was) was too small and the width of each line was begin set as 0. I tried to make the screen 400,000 pixels wide but my computer crashed. So I made a compromise by making the program sample only about a quarter of each of the books. The background colour was impossible to create using numbers from the text so is merely a preset background for each of the books. What you see on the next three pages is about a quarter of each of the following books, A Study in Scarlet, A Picture of Dorian Gray & The Great Gatsby, converted using my algorithm into the visual world. On the right is the program I wrote to make these pieces.

I think that how we convert the language of computers so it can be understood in our visual world is fascinating and completely varied results beautiful. It is strange how one can translate the completely differently constructed worlds into each other’s medium.

item.title: Nebulaic Toaster- A first foray into python, Summer 2013
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
https://github.com/chromebookbob/nebulaic-toaster

I set out to learn python during the summer of 2012. Using an excellent tutorial website, I finished with a great interest in programming and decided to write a text-based game. This game, with its silly name can be found at the link above.

item.title: Lottery Numbers, visually represented in python, August 2014
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I used pygame again for this piece,

I took the winning lottery numbers from the last two years and used each number to represent a factor in each of the circles. The first three represent the r, g and b numbers for the colour of the circle, the fourth and fifth represent the x and y values of the circle, its position, and the last represents the radius, the size. The result is a visual representation of the sets.

item.title: Cinema 4D, 3D Modeling & Animation- October 2014 onwards
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I have recently been introduced to a piece of software called Cinema 4D, it's a 3d modeling and animation suite which many big studios use. I have been learning how to use it recently, and I have produced a few short animations using some basic tools. Here are some screenshots & clips from them:

[embed]https://vimeo.com/108695828[/embed]

[embed]http://https://vimeo.com/108695827[/embed]

I really like Cinema 4D, it has incredible lighting effects, loads of cool physics and explosions and it runs on fairly standard computers. I will continue with my efforts on C4D.

item.title: Lightyear. A game about loss, depression and space- January 2015
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Download the game: http://chromebookbob.itch.io/lightyear Read the reviews: http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2015/01/14/freeware-garden-lightyear/ http://riotpixels.com/pikseli-darom-22-yanvarya-2015/ I wrote this game/interactive story after finding out about Twine, an interactive fiction game making tool. It is mostly visual but I used a fair bit of javascript and HTML5 to shoehorn in images, sound and different fonts. The story came from one that I had been thinking about for a long time, and I had tried to make into a game using Stencyl. I found that the interactive fiction medium was going to be much better for this type of game, as it was heavily story based and only really took place in one room. When I released the game, it sat on the internet for a day or two, with my brother and friends downloading it. They helped me squash a few bugs, meanwhile I had ut out some emails to little game review sites and a couple of bigger ones. Much to my surprise, I cam out of my Latin mock exam that day, checked the analytics of my game's page and they had skyrocketed. It turned out that the person I had emailed at Rock Paper Shotgun had played the game and put a post up about it in the Freeware Garden section. I was very happy and since then I have had nearly 750 downloads of the game. I plan in the future to write a prequel, as I have some ideas and a load of cold war archival photos which I would love to incorporate.

item.title: A Quick Swim To Clear Your Head, An atmospheric swimming simulator- February 2015
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I made this game as an art project and to learn how to use Stencyl, a block based game making tool. It is supposed to explore the mind of a man in existential crisis. I took the idea of the night sky being a sea of stars and used the physics engine in Stencyl to make the stars react, like leaves on a lake, to the wake of the swimming man. I added an earth beachball and the lilo both of which are brightly coloured to contrast the deep blue of the sky. Reviews: http://abnormalmapping.com/2015/01/22/uncertain-futures/ Play the game: http://chromebookbob.itch.io/a-quick-swim-to-clear-your-head

item.title: Crazyflie, Quadcopter Light Painting- January 2015
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This is the crazyflie 2.0 micro drone, it's an open development platform, so you can program it in python, it's arduino compatible etc. I received a parrot AR drone for christmas, but when I was flying it with my brother on boxing day with altitude hold on it decided to fly away. It shot up into the sky and then the motors cut out and it plummeted to the ground. I had a faulty unit so I got the money back and, as I was now gun shy, decided to go for a smaller quadcopter. I developed this method of photography for my art GCSE project. Here are some examples:

item.title: Crazyflie, Opencv and Kinect- February 2015 Onwards
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I wanted to get into using python to control the crazyflie so I got to work with opencv. This is a python library that can recognise objects and put a bounding box around them. I wrote a simple script that altered the thrust and roll depending on the position of the drone relative to a point on the screen. This worked, but it only controlled the drone in two dimensions so I received a number of slashes to the face through out of control computer flying. It also corrected itself too slowly. I moved on to think of a different solution. I came across a project by omwdunkley, who did his masters dissertation on the crazyflie, to control the crazyflie through kinect and ROS. I bought a cheap kinect off ebay and tried to get it working. I tried getting it running in virtualbox, but my computer couldn't handle it so I migrated to an old desktop pc with xubuntu on. I managed to install all the necessary libraries for ROS and get the programs running: Unfortunately, given that the kinect feeds in data from two cameras and processes it into 3d points: The computer I was using just didn't have the processing power to handle so much data at one time. I will endeavour in the future to get it working with less data readings (or maybe try to get usb3.0 working with my pc). My end goal was to use this control software to be able to drag the drone around the screen and draw with it like one would a pen. I could draw my light painting images in the real world.

item.title: Art GCSE Final Piece Installation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: My final piece consisted of a load of declassified documents about phone tapping etc. and old personal photos hanging above a desk on which a phone sat. I had wired up the phone to a raspberry pi so and had written a python script so that every so often it would ring, and upon picking up it played a randomly chosen recorded phone conversation out loud. See the video below: [embed]https://vimeo.com/130787465[/embed] This piece was similar in concept to my other final piece:   This piece had a homemade projector behind the sheet running a selection of videos cropped into each piece of the figure's (JFK) silhouette.

item.title: Learning Kivy, Nebualic Toaster V2- Summer 2014
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
https://github.com/chromebookbob/Nebulaic-Toaster-Kivy

I heard about kivy (http://kivy.org) in june of 2014, it is a python module that allows you to create programs with guis. It caught my eye because kivy applications work cross platform and are touch enabled, so I could write the program on mac and it would easily port to android, ios, windows or linux.

As I was learning the basics with a youtube series, I started to create a game. I made everything myself, discovering that lone game development takes a long time. By the end of the summer I had a game that needed a bit more storyline, but was essentially playable.

Here are some screenshots from the game:

item.title: Ethics, A game about making decisions- September 2014 onwards
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Since September I have been developing my python by making another game. I had an idea for a game in which the player works for a government department set up to make decisions for the rest of the country. The player has to make the decisions and as the seriousness of the decisions increases, justify them.

The game is visually similar to nebulaic toaster v2 at the moment. My second go at kivy has been much more successful, the program is much less cluttered, and once the framework is written I should only need to add entries to a text file to progress the story.

screenshots so far:
